stories.title: The Creation Story
stories.subtitle: Genesis 1-2
stories.description: Experience the wonder of God speaking the universe into existence, day by day, culminating in the creation of humanity in His image.

segments.title: In the Beginning
segments.content:
Before time itself began, before the first ray of light pierced the void, there was God. The universe lay formless and empty, a vast expanse of darkness hovering over the deep waters. The Spirit of God moved across this primordial canvas, pregnant with possibility.

Then God spoke. His voice, the first sound to ever echo through existence, called forth light itself: "Let there be light." And there was light—brilliant, pure, and good. God separated this new radiance from the darkness, calling one Day and the other Night. Thus ended the first day, with evening and morning marking the rhythm that would govern all of creation.
segments.reflection_question: What does it mean that God's first creative act was to bring light into darkness?

key_term.briefMeaning: Physical light, but also symbolizing God's presence and truth

segments.title: The Waters Above and Below
segments.content:
On the second day, God turned His attention to the vast waters that covered everything. With a word, He created an expanse—a great dome stretching across the heavens. This firmament separated the waters below from the waters above, creating the sky that would one day hold clouds and stars.

God called this expanse "Heaven," and though this day's work receives no explicit declaration of goodness, it set the stage for all that would follow. The second evening came, and the second morning dawned upon a world now divided between sea and sky.
segments.reflection_question: Why do you think God chose to create through separation and distinction?

key_term.briefMeaning: An expanse or dome; the visible sky separating earthly and heavenly waters

segments.title: Land, Seas, and Growing Things
segments.content:
The third day brought dramatic transformation. God commanded the waters under heaven to gather together, revealing dry ground for the first time. The vast oceans found their boundaries, and solid earth emerged—mountains, valleys, and plains rising from the receding seas. God named the dry ground "Land" and the gathered waters "Seas." And it was good.

But God was not finished with this day. He spoke again, and the barren earth burst forth with life. Grasses carpeted the hills, seed-bearing plants of every variety sprouted from the soil, and trees rose toward the sky, their branches heavy with fruit. Each plant carried within itself the seed for future generations. God saw all this abundant growth, and it was good.
segments.reflection_question: What does the abundance of plant life tell us about God's character as Creator?

segments.title: Lights in the Heavens
segments.content:
On the fourth day, God filled the expanse of heaven with lights. The greater light—the blazing sun—would rule the day, warming the earth and giving energy to the growing plants. The lesser light—the gentle moon—would govern the night, reflecting the sun's glory in silver tones.

But God did not stop there. He scattered countless stars across the velvet darkness, each one a sun in its own right, burning in the infinite distance. These celestial bodies would serve as signs and seasons, marking days and years for the creatures yet to come. The cosmos hummed with divine order. And God saw that it was good.
segments.reflection_question: How do the sun, moon, and stars reveal God's wisdom in designing creation?

segments.title: Creatures of Sea and Sky
segments.content:
The fifth day brought movement and song to creation. God filled the seas with living creatures—from the tiniest fish to the great sea monsters that churned through the deep. Every stream, river, lake, and ocean teemed with life in dazzling variety.

Above the waters, birds took flight for the first time. Their wings beat against the air, their calls echoed across the young world. From eagles soaring on thermals to hummingbirds hovering over flowers, the sky came alive with feathered multitudes. God blessed these creatures with the first blessing recorded in Scripture: "Be fruitful and multiply." And it was good.
segments.reflection_question: Why do you think God blessed the animals with fruitfulness before He created humans?

segments.title: Beasts and Humanity
segments.content:
The sixth day dawned on a world ready for its final inhabitants. God commanded the earth to bring forth living creatures—livestock, wild beasts, and everything that creeps along the ground. Lions, cattle, serpents, and countless others filled the land, each according to its kind.

Then came the crowning moment. God said, "Let us make mankind in our image, after our likeness." This was something new—a creature that would bear the very image of the Creator. God formed the first man from the dust of the ground and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life. Adam opened his eyes to gaze upon a world of wonder, and the first human heart began to beat.
segments.reflection_question: What does it mean to be made in God's image?

key_term.briefMeaning: A representation or likeness; humans uniquely reflect God's nature

segments.title: The Seventh Day Rest
segments.content:
By the seventh day, God had finished all His work of creation. The heavens and earth stood complete in all their vast array—light and darkness, sea and sky, land and vegetation, sun, moon and stars, creatures of water, air, and land, and finally humanity bearing God's own image.

So God rested. Not from weariness, for the Almighty knows no exhaustion, but as a declaration that His work was complete and perfect. He blessed the seventh day and made it holy, setting it apart from all other days. This pattern of work and rest would become a gift to humanity—a rhythm woven into the very fabric of creation.

God looked at everything He had made, and behold, it was very good.
segments.reflection_question: What can we learn from God's example of rest after completing His work?

key_term.briefMeaning: To cease, to rest; the origin of Sabbath

stories.title: The Prodigal Son
stories.subtitle: Luke 15:11-32
stories.description: Jesus tells the powerful story of a wayward son, a patient father, and the boundless nature of God's love and forgiveness.

segments.title: A Son's Demand
segments.content:
A certain man had two sons. The younger son, restless and eager for independence, approached his father with an audacious request: "Father, give me the share of property that is coming to me."

In that culture, such a demand was unthinkable—essentially wishing his father dead. Yet the father, showing remarkable grace, divided his property between his two sons. The younger gathered all he had and set off for a distant country, leaving behind his home, his family, and his father's love.
segments.reflection_question: What drove the younger son to demand his inheritance early?

segments.title: Reckless Living and Ruin
segments.content:
In that distant country, the son squandered his wealth in reckless living. Every coin his father had worked to earn, every possession that represented years of labor—all of it slipped through his fingers in pursuit of pleasure.

Then famine struck the land. With his money gone and his stomach empty, the young man found himself in desperate straits. He hired himself out to feed pigs—the most degrading work imaginable for a Jewish man. So hungry was he that even the pods the pigs ate looked appetizing. No one gave him anything.
segments.reflection_question: How does sin often lead us further from home than we ever intended to go?

segments.title: Coming to His Senses
segments.content:
Sitting among the pigs, covered in filth, the young man finally came to his senses. He remembered his father's house, where even the hired servants had food to spare while he was perishing with hunger.

"I will arise and go to my father," he resolved. He rehearsed his confession: "Father, I have sinned against heaven and before you. I am no longer worthy to be called your son. Treat me as one of your hired servants." With trembling hope, he rose and began the long journey home.
segments.reflection_question: What does it take for us to 'come to our senses' about our own wandering from God?

segments.title: The Father's Welcome
segments.content:
While the son was still a long way off, his father saw him. This detail is remarkable—the father must have been watching, waiting, hoping for this very moment. Filled with compassion, the father ran to his son, threw his arms around him, and kissed him.

The son began his rehearsed confession: "Father, I have sinned against heaven and before you. I am no longer worthy—" But the father interrupted, turning to his servants: "Quick! Bring the best robe and put it on him. Put a ring on his finger and sandals on his feet. Bring the fattened calf and kill it. Let's have a feast and celebrate!"
segments.reflection_question: What does the father's response tell us about how God welcomes repentant sinners?

key_term.briefMeaning: Deep, gut-level emotion; moved in one's inner being

segments.title: The Elder Brother's Anger
segments.content:
The elder son had been working in the field. Hearing music and dancing, he asked a servant what was happening. When he learned his brother had returned and his father was celebrating, he became angry and refused to go in.

The father came out to plead with him. "Look," the son said, "all these years I've served you faithfully, yet you never gave me even a young goat to celebrate with my friends. But when this son of yours who squandered your property comes home, you kill the fattened calf for him!"

"Son," the father said gently, "you are always with me, and everything I have is yours. But we had to celebrate because this brother of yours was dead and is alive again; he was lost and is found."
segments.reflection_question: In what ways might we be like the elder brother, resentful of God's grace toward others?

stories.title: David: From Shepherd to King
stories.subtitle: 1 Samuel 16 - 2 Samuel 5
stories.description: Follow David's remarkable journey from humble shepherd boy to the greatest king of Israel, through triumph, persecution, and God's faithful provision.

segments.title: The Unlikely Chosen One
segments.content:
The prophet Samuel arrived in Bethlehem with a secret mission from God: to anoint a new king from among the sons of Jesse. As Jesse's sons passed before him, Samuel was impressed by each one's appearance—surely one of these tall, strong men was God's chosen.

But God had other plans. "Do not consider his appearance or his height," the Lord told Samuel. "The Lord does not look at the things people look at. People look at the outward appearance, but the Lord looks at the heart."

Seven sons passed before Samuel, and none was chosen. "Are these all your sons?" Samuel asked. Jesse replied, "There is still the youngest, but he is tending the sheep." They sent for David, and when the ruddy, handsome youth arrived, the Lord said, "Rise and anoint him; this is the one."
segments.reflection_question: What does God's choice of David teach us about how He values people?

key_term.briefMeaning: To consecrate by pouring oil; setting apart for God's purpose

segments.title: The Giant's Challenge
segments.content:
The armies of Israel faced the Philistines in the Valley of Elah. Each morning and evening for forty days, a giant named Goliath emerged from the Philistine camp to mock Israel and challenge them to single combat. Standing over nine feet tall, clad in bronze armor, he terrified every Israelite soldier.

David had come to bring food to his brothers. When he heard Goliath's taunts and saw Israel's fear, righteous anger stirred in his heart. "Who is this uncircumcised Philistine that he should defy the armies of the living God?" David asked. His brothers scorned him, but David's words reached King Saul.
segments.reflection_question: What 'giants' in our lives seem impossible to defeat without God's help?

segments.title: Faith Over Fear
segments.content:
Saul tried to give David his own armor, but it was too heavy—David was not used to it. Instead, the shepherd boy chose five smooth stones from a stream and armed himself with his sling and his faith.

Goliath saw David approaching and was insulted. "Am I a dog, that you come at me with sticks?" he roared. "Come here, and I'll give your flesh to the birds!"

But David replied with words that still echo through the ages: "You come against me with sword and spear and javelin, but I come against you in the name of the Lord Almighty, the God of the armies of Israel, whom you have defied. This day the Lord will deliver you into my hands."
segments.reflection_question: How can we face our challenges 'in the name of the Lord' like David did?

segments.title: The Giant Falls
segments.content:
David ran toward the battle line to meet Goliath. Reaching into his bag, he drew out a stone, fitted it to his sling, and let it fly. The stone struck the giant's forehead, sinking deep. Goliath fell face down on the ground.

Then David stood over the fallen giant, drew Goliath's own sword, and struck off his head. When the Philistines saw their champion was dead, they fled in terror. Israel pursued them all the way to Gath and Ekron, and that day the Lord gave Israel a great victory through an unlikely shepherd boy who trusted in His name.
segments.reflection_question: How does David's victory point forward to a greater victory over evil?

stories.title: Noah and the Flood
stories.subtitle: Genesis 6-9
stories.description: When the world became corrupt, God found one righteous man. Experience the story of Noah's faith, the great flood, and God's covenant promise.

segments.title: A World Gone Wrong
segments.content:
The Lord saw that human wickedness had become great on the earth. Every inclination of the thoughts of the human heart was only evil all the time. The Creator who had looked at His work and called it very good now grieved over what humanity had become.

But Noah was different. In a generation drowning in corruption, Noah found favor in the eyes of the Lord. He was a righteous man, blameless among the people of his time, and he walked faithfully with God.
segments.reflection_question: What does it mean to 'walk with God' when everyone around you is going the other direction?

segments.title: The Ark
segments.content:
God revealed His plan to Noah: He would bring a flood to destroy all life under the heavens. But He would establish a covenant with Noah. "Make yourself an ark," God commanded, giving precise instructions for its construction—300 cubits long, 50 cubits wide, 30 cubits high.

Noah obeyed. For decades, he and his family worked on the massive vessel, a monument to faith in a world that mocked them. Year after year, they cut timber, shaped beams, and sealed the ark with pitch, trusting God's warning of a flood when rain itself was perhaps unknown.
segments.reflection_question: How does Noah's obedience inspire you to trust God even when His instructions seem strange?

key_term.briefMeaning: A vessel or box; used only here and for baby Moses's basket

segments.title: The Waters Rise
segments.content:
When Noah was 600 years old, the Lord told him to enter the ark with his family and the animals. Two by two, seven pairs of clean animals and one pair of every other kind came to Noah as if guided by an unseen hand.

Then the Lord shut him in. The fountains of the great deep burst open, the floodgates of heaven opened, and rain fell for forty days and forty nights. The waters rose until even the highest mountains were covered. Every living thing on the face of the earth was wiped out—only Noah and those with him in the ark remained.
segments.reflection_question: What does the phrase 'the Lord shut him in' reveal about God's protection?

segments.title: The Waters Recede
segments.content:
God remembered Noah. He sent a wind over the earth, and the waters receded. The ark came to rest on the mountains of Ararat. Noah sent out a raven, then a dove. The first time, the dove returned finding no rest. The second time, it returned with an olive leaf. The third time, it did not return—the earth was drying.

After more than a year in the ark, God commanded Noah to come out. Noah built an altar and offered sacrifices to the Lord. The Lord smelled the pleasing aroma and made a promise: never again would He destroy all living creatures with a flood.
segments.reflection_question: How does Noah's first act after leaving the ark (worship) set an example for us?

segments.title: The Rainbow Covenant
segments.content:
God blessed Noah and his sons, commanding them to be fruitful and multiply. He established His covenant with all living creatures: never again would a flood destroy the earth. As the sign of this everlasting promise, God set His rainbow in the clouds.

"Whenever the rainbow appears in the clouds," God said, "I will remember my covenant between me and you and all living creatures." From that day forward, the rainbow has stood as a reminder of God's faithfulness—a bridge of color between heaven and earth, testifying to His mercy.
segments.reflection_question: What other covenants has God made, and how do they show His faithful character?

key_term.briefMeaning: A binding agreement; God's unilateral promise to His people

stories.title: The Good Samaritan
stories.subtitle: Luke 10:25-37
stories.description: Jesus answers the question 'Who is my neighbor?' with a story that challenges our assumptions about love, mercy, and who truly keeps God's commands.

segments.title: The Lawyer's Question
segments.content:
An expert in the law stood up to test Jesus. "Teacher," he asked, "what must I do to inherit eternal life?" Jesus turned the question back to him: "What is written in the Law?"

The lawyer answered correctly: "Love the Lord your God with all your heart, soul, strength, and mind, and love your neighbor as yourself." Jesus told him he had answered rightly—do this and you will live.

But the lawyer, wanting to justify himself, pressed further: "And who is my neighbor?" It was a common debate—did 'neighbor' mean only fellow Jews, or perhaps also converts? Jesus answered with a story.
segments.reflection_question: Why do you think the lawyer wanted to 'justify himself'?

segments.title: The Attack
segments.content:
"A man was going down from Jerusalem to Jericho," Jesus began. This road was notoriously dangerous—a winding, seventeen-mile descent through rocky wilderness, perfect for ambush.

Bandits fell upon the traveler. They stripped him of his clothes, beat him mercilessly, and left him half dead by the roadside. There he lay, bloodied and helpless, unable to move, unsure if anyone would come to his aid.
segments.reflection_question: What kinds of people today are left 'half dead' by life's circumstances?

segments.title: Those Who Passed By
segments.content:
By chance, a priest came down that road. Seeing the wounded man, he passed by on the other side. Perhaps he feared ritual defilement, or bandits still lurking nearby, or simply the inconvenience of involvement.

A Levite came next—another religious leader, another man who knew God's law. He too approached, looked at the victim, and passed by on the other side. Two men who should have known better, two men who taught others about God's love, and neither stopped to help.
segments.reflection_question: What excuses do we make for not helping those in need around us?

segments.title: The Unexpected Hero
segments.content:
Then came a Samaritan—a member of a people despised by Jews, considered heretics and half-breeds. Every listener expected him to be the villain of the story.

But when the Samaritan saw the wounded man, he was moved with compassion. He went to him, bandaged his wounds, pouring oil and wine to cleanse and soothe. He put the man on his own donkey, brought him to an inn, and took care of him through the night. The next day, he gave the innkeeper two denarii—two days' wages—with the promise to reimburse any additional expense.

"Which of these three proved to be a neighbor?" Jesus asked. The lawyer could not even bring himself to say 'the Samaritan.' "The one who showed mercy," he answered. Jesus replied simply: "Go and do likewise."
segments.reflection_question: How does this parable challenge our definitions of who deserves our help?

key_term.briefMeaning: One who is near; Jesus redefines this as anyone we can show mercy to
